Question_1.Context: In the study, what method was used to determine the antioxidant activity of the extracts?
Question_1.Question: What method was used to determine the antioxidant activity of the extracts?
Question_1.Source: The antioxidant activity was determined using a DPPH free radical scavenging assay, with slight modifications.

Question_2.Context: What was the primary anthocyanin found in the 'Ariheuk' bran extract (ABE)?
Question_2.Question: What was the primary anthocyanin found in the 'Ariheuk' bran extract (ABE)?
Question_2.Source: Several anthocyanins were identified in ABE: peonidin-3-O-glucoside, peonidin-3-O-malonylglucoside, cyanidin-3-O-rutinoside, delphinidin-3-O-rutinoside, cyanidin-3-O-(6″-malonyl-glucoside), and peonidin-3-O-glucoside.

Question_3.Context: What was the primary anthocyanin found in the 'Geumgang' bran extract (GBE)?
Question_3.Question: What was the primary anthocyanin found in the 'Geumgang' bran extract (GBE)?
Question_3.Source: The significant metabolites in GBE-F2 included DL-tryptophan (m/z 205), L-phenylalanine (m/z 166), corymboside (m/z 565), and 14 other compounds.

Question_4.Context: What was the method used to identify the active metabolites in the subfractions of the extracts?
Question_4.Question: What was the method used to identify the active metabolites in the subfractions of the extracts?
Question_4.Source: To further identify the active metabolites with anti-inflammatory activity in subfractions (ABE and GBE), LC-mass spectrometry (MS) analysis was performed.

Question_5.Context: What was the primary component used to visually compare metabolomic variations between ABEs and GBEs?
Question_5.Question: What was the primary component used to visually compare metabolomic variations between ABEs and GBEs?
Question_5.Source: PCA also revealed a metabolomic variation in ABEs, which can explain 92.6% of the variance in principal components 1 and 2.

Question_6.Context: What was the primary component that distinguished ABE-F2 from ABE-F1 and ABE-F3?
Question_6.Question: What was the primary component that distinguished ABE-F2 from ABE-F1 and ABE-F3?
Question_6.Source: ABE-F2, the active fraction, was distinguished from ABE-F1 and ABE-F3 by principal components 1 (PC1, 73.0%) and principal component 2 (PC2, 19.6%).

Question_7.Context: Which subfraction exhibited the highest total anthocyanin content (TAC) among all subfractions?
Question_7.Question: Which subfraction exhibited the highest total anthocyanin content (TAC) among all subfractions?
Question_7.Source: All subfractions of ABE had a higher TAC than GBE, with ABE-F3 exhibiting the highest value, followed by ABE-F2 and ABE-F1.

Question_8.Context: Which extract exhibited significantly higher DPPH free radical scavenging activity than the other extract?
Question_8.Question: Which extract exhibited significantly higher DPPH free radical scavenging activity than the other extract?
Question_8.Source: ABE exhibited significantly higher DPPH free radical scavenging activity than GBE.

Question_9.Context: Which subfraction demonstrated the most potent suppression of ROS generation among all subfractions?
Question_9.Question: Which subfraction demonstrated the most potent suppression of ROS generation among all subfractions?
Question_9.Source: Notably, the F2 subfraction demonstrated the most potent suppression of ROS generation among all subfractions.

Question_10.Context: Which extract had a higher relative anti-inflammatory activity based on the assessed biomarkers?
Question_10.Question: Which extract had a higher relative anti-inflammatory activity based on the assessed biomarkers?
Question_10.Source: Based on the assessed biomarkers, the relative anti-inflammatory activity of ABE was higher than that of GBE.
